content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It’s a good exercise for beginners to practice string manipulation, loops, and formatting output

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Really nice!
I like this type of COC. It was interesting, more complex than I expected, but still very simple in practice.
I really enjoyed coding this one.
I think it could be interesting for beginners to learn the basics, and for more experienced programmers to just have fun.


My solution (completed in ~2minutes) :
n = list(input())
s=""
ind=len(n)
for i in range(len(n)):
    if n[i]!="0":
        s+=n[i]+"x1"+((ind-int(i)-1)*"0")+"+"
print(s[:-1])

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This clash seems simple on first glance but might cause some problems with parsing and dealing with zeros during implementation. Still doable within 5 minutes though.

Expanded Notation is an usefull concept from elementary math education. As such this challenge has real world relevance.

The task is basically straightforward, but  requires some work with loops or similar. String formating is always an interesting basic exercise.

It adds an interesting twist because you have to consider zero digits.

One thing I would advise is having a testcase with a really large number. Maybe some edgecases like palindrome numbers and single digits.

An intertesting exercise, with a slightly higer difficulty would be the reverse conversion.

Cases
* Please add a pair of cases where [[n]] = 6 in one and 7 in the other.

* Please add a pair of cases where [[n]] starts with a completely random mix of digits from 4 to 9 and ends with at least 2 zeros.

* Please add a pair of cases where [[n]] contains a completely random mix of digits from 4 to 9 and 2 non-consecutive groups of zeros (e.g. 400908, 605007).

Thanks.
Another thing: I am not sure if it makes sense to have this challenge in reverse mode, as it is kinda obvious what the task is anyway if you take a look at it.
Yeah, but if its doable in reverse, put it in reverse. Isn't that what it is like?
I agree with @Delicious31415. Reverse mode tasks can range from easily understandable to not overly cryptic.
